page.title: 16DICK TURPIN IN THE SAMPFORDS
page.content: Dick Turpin 1706 _ 1739 Dick Turpin was born 1706, he lived in Hempstead a village near this area where his father was an Innkeeper. The Sampfords was one of his local haunts. As a young man he was apprenticed to a butcher. He joined a gang of local thieves and stole farm animals and deer. He was first arrested for stealing a cow and calf. On escaping from custody he joined a band of robbers. He worked with Tom King as a highwayman, robbing everyone who travelled on the highways between London and Cambridge. He eventually killed King in London in an argument with a constable, when King accidentally got in the way. He fled to Yorkshire where he set up a horse dealing business under a false name. He was finally arrested in York for horse stealing and hanged.
